title: Senate bid to scrap flight red tape fails
text:
A crossbench senator has branded the major parties "cowards" for failing to relax maintenance requirements for non-emergency medical charity flights.

Centre Alliance's Rex Patrick tried to scrap regulations placed on Angel Flight, a charity that co-ordinates flights to attend medical appointments, after two deadly crashes over six years.

The coalition and Labor voted against the disallowance motion despite a bipartisan parliamentary committee recommending removing additional maintenance requirements imposed on the flights.

As opposition frontbencher Louise Pratt confirmed Labor would not support the move, Senator Patrick shouted "because you're cowards" across the chamber.

Senior cabinet minister Simon Birmingham said the government supported the independence of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

"These measures are a practical approach to mitigating any flight risks," he told parliament on Thursday.

He said CASA's advice was appropriate and proportionate, with the regulation expected to affect less than 10 per cent of private aircraft.

The Senate committee found there was no link between maintenance and two triple-fatality crashes in Victoria and South Australia in 2011 and 2017 respectively.

Senator Patrick said Australian Transport Safety Bureau's finding that Angel Flights were seven times riskier than private aviation had caused a significant rise in the organisation's insurance premium.

He echoed the criticism in the parliamentary committee's report which raised concerns with the ATSB's research.

"Lies, damned lies and statistics is the saying," the SA senator said.

Senator Patrick said "shame on all Nationals" for voting against it, given the services Angel Flight provided to regional areas.

"We still have an organisation in CASA that is intent - it's their modus operandi - to shut down general aviation," he said.

Senator Pratt said Labor was also keen to protect CASA's independence and noted the government was still considering how to respond to the committee's recommendations.
description: A crossbench senator has branded the major parties
